title: Nestlé Just Launched the Plant-Based Awesome Burger—And It’s Packed With Protein
text:
From Prevention

Nestlé’s new plant-based Awesome Burger, which is made by Sweet Earth Foods, is launching in grocery stores starting October 1.

The Awesome Burger’s main ingredient is pea protein, and it packs 260 calories and nearly 30 grams of protein.

Dietitians share their thoughts on the Awesome Burger’s nutrition facts, and offer the healthiest way to enjoy it.

There’s a new arrival in the plant-based burger market: Nestlé is launching the Awesome Burger.

The burger is made by Sweet Earth Foods (which Nestlé owns) and, like other faux meat burgers on the market right now, it’s designed to look and feel like the real thing. Awesome Burgers come in a two-pack of patties and they’ll be sold at supermarkets around the country—including Wegmans, FredMeyer, Safeway, Stop & Shop, HyVee, and more—starting October 1.

In case you’re having trouble keeping track of all the faux meat options out there, this is the third big plant-based burger launch in recent months, joining Impossible Burgers and Beyond Burgers.

What is the Awesome Burger made of?

The big ingredient is textured pea protein (Beyond Burger is also made with a pea protein isolate). Other than that, it has water, coconut oil, wheat gluten, canola oil, vinegar, corn starch, salt, and a few other ingredients.

Awesome Burger nutrition

Photo credit: Sweet Earth Foods More

As for nutrition, a quarter-pound patty contains the following:

Calories: 260

Fat: 15 grams

Saturated fat: 7 grams

Sodium: 400 milligrams

Carbohydrates: 9 grams

Fiber: 6 grams

Protein: 26 grams

Is the Awesome Burger healthy?

It’s not bad. “Overall I think Nestlé did a great job with this burger by offering a healthy plant-based option,” says Keri Gans, RDN, author of The Small Change Diet. “Most impressive is that it provides 6 grams of fiber per patty, an important nutrient that most people don’t consume enough of in their daily diets.”

That said, this is “very highly processed,” points out Karen Ansel, RDN, co-author of Healthy in a Hurry. “The fact that it’s 100 percent plant-based makes it seem like it’s healthy, but if you take a deeper dive into the nutrition stats and the ingredient list, you’ll see that most of its fat comes from coconut oil, which (despite its health halo) is still filled with saturated fat,” she says. “It also contains a fair amount of sodium.”

From a nutritional standpoint “it looks a lot like a lean burger,” says dietitian Scott Keatley, RD, of Keatley Medical Nutrition Therapy, and he agrees that it has great fiber content. “However, this burger packs a lot more sodium than your traditional beef burger and what may be most lacking is vitamin B12 and iron, which are essential for red blood cells that do, well, just about everything in your body,” he says.

While the burger is plant-based, the ingredients are “broken down, pulverized, and mixed together” and “may not deliver the same health benefits,” Ansel says.

However, nutrition is not the only factor here. If you’re looking to cut back on how much red meat you eat (for environmental or other ethical reasons) while still enjoying a burger, Gans says this is a good option. She recommends topping it with avocado, tomato, lettuce, and onion on a 100 percent whole grain bun to max out the health benefits.

But overall, Keatley says you should treat this (and other plant-based burgers) like a burger. “For every nutrient you gain, you lose others,” he says. “But give it a try. If you love the taste, then add them into your burger rotation. But if the taste leaves you wanting the beef burger, it’s okay to go back.”
